original_title: Building a Weather Display in Rust
original_content:
Weve seen a lot of weather displays over the years, and plenty of the more modern ones have been using some form of electronic paper. So what makes this particular build from [Harry Stern] different? The fact that the firmware running on the ESP32 microcontroller at its heart was developed in Rust.
The weather station itself is capable of operating for several months on its rechargeable NiMH battery bank. The Rust section of the project is in two parts, the first of which runs on a server which downloads the weather data and aggregates it into an image. The second part runs on the ESP32 using esp-idf which configures peripherals, turns on and connects to Wi-Fi, retrieves the image from the server, displays the image and then puts the display to sleep. By doing the heavy lifting on the server, the display should be able to run for longer than it would if everything was happening on the ESP32.
The project code is available from this GitHub page which should allow even Rust beginners to follow along, and the case file is also available for those with a 3D printer. [Harry] has a few upgrades planned for future releases as well, including a snap-fit case, a custom PCB, and improved voltage regulator for better battery life, and enhanced error handling for the weather API. And Rust isnt the only interesting part of this project, either. As prices for e-paper displays continue to fall, more and more of them are found in projects like weather stations and even complete laptops which use these displays exclusively.
title: ESP32マイコンを使った気象表示装置のRust開発
body: 天気表示装置は電子ペーパーを使用していますが、このプロジェクトはESP32マイクロコントローラーのファームウェアがRustで開発されている点が異なります。ESP32は画像を表示してディスプレイをスリープさせる役割を果たします。サーバー側で重い処理を行うことで、ディスプレイの動作時間が延びます。3Dプリンターでケースを作ることも可能です。今後もアップグレード予定があります。電子ペーパーディスプレイは価格が下がっており、天気予報や完全なラップトップなどに広く使われるようになっています。
